relationships.notes: Consistently accompanies Jesus at pivotal healings, the transfiguration, and resurrection appearances as part of the closest disciple circle.
The two sons of Zebedee leave their fishing business together to follow Jesus and remain paired in ministry until James’s martyrdom.
Frequently paired with Peter during Jesus’s ministry, in resurrection narratives, and in Jerusalem leadership, culminating in Paul’s recognition of both as pillars.

traits.calling_and_background: Presented as a Galilean fisherman, son of Zebedee and brother of James, called by Jesus while working in the family boat.
traits.inner_circle_status: Belongs to the small inner circle with Peter and James who witness key revelatory moments like the raising of Jairus’s daughter, the transfiguration, and Gethsemane.
traits.temperament_and_nickname: Together with James he is given the nickname Boanerges, 'sons of thunder', suggesting a forceful or volatile temperament.
traits.role_in_ministry: Appears as a close associate of Jesus who accompanies him at crucial moments but has little individual speech or distinct theological profile.
traits.apocalyptic_and_eschatological_context: Present on the Mount of Olives when Jesus delivers the apocalyptic discourse, marking him as a recipient of Jesus’s private eschatological teaching.
traits.passion_presence: Accompanies Jesus into Gethsemane with Peter and James, sharing in the failure to stay awake during Jesus’s distress before arrest.

traits.calling_and_background: Named among the first disciples called from fishing in Galilee as the son of Zebedee and brother of James.
traits.inner_circle_status: Like Mark, Matthew places him in the inner trio with Peter and James at the transfiguration and in Gethsemane.
traits.ambition_and_status_request: Via the request of their mother, John and James are associated with a bid for privileged seats in Jesus’s kingdom, revealing concerns with status and honor.
traits.instruction_on_greatness: Jesus uses this episode to teach about servant leadership and suffering, implicitly correcting the ambitions of John and his brother.
traits.passion_presence: Appears among the closest companions who accompany Jesus during the final hours before his arrest, again without an individual speaking role.

traits.calling_and_background: Identified as a partner of Simon Peter in the fishing business and as son of Zebedee, called after the miraculous catch of fish.
traits.inner_circle_status: Included with Peter and James at the raising of Jairus’s daughter and the transfiguration, marking him as one of Jesus’s closest companions.
traits.zeal_and_sectarian_impulses: Portrayed as quick to defend group boundaries, wanting to forbid an outsider exorcist and, with James, proposing to call down fire on an inhospitable Samaritan village.
traits.correction_by_jesus: Jesus rebukes these exclusionary and violent impulses, using John’s missteps to articulate a more generous or nonviolent mission posture.
traits.name_in_apostolic_lists: Appears in the list of the Twelve with no added title beyond apostolic designation.

traits.narrative_presence: Not individually foregrounded by name in the main body of the gospel; the focus falls instead on an unnamed 'disciple whom Jesus loved'.
traits.sons_of_zebedee_reference: Mentioned only collectively as one of the 'sons of Zebedee' present at the post-resurrection fishing scene by the Sea of Tiberias.
traits.relationship_to_beloved_disciple_traditi: Later Christian tradition often identified the beloved disciple with John son of Zebedee, but the gospel itself keeps that disciple anonymous, leaving any identification unstated within the text.

traits.leadership_with_peter: Appears as Peter’s close associate in the early Jerusalem community, going with him to the temple and participating in the healing of the lame man.
traits.boldness_before_authorities: Stands with Peter before the Sanhedrin, noted for boldness despite being seen as uneducated and ordinary.
traits.role_in_samaria_mission: Sent with Peter to Samaria to confirm and extend the mission there, laying hands on new believers so they receive the Holy Spirit.
traits.gradual_fading_from_narrative: After the early Jerusalem episodes his presence recedes, with later references to him mainly in relation to James, who is martyred as 'the brother of John'.

traits.leadership_in_jerusalem: Named by Paul as one of the reputed 'pillars' of the Jerusalem community alongside James and Cephas.
traits.agreement_with_pauline_mission: Participates in the recognition of Paul and Barnabas’s mission to the Gentiles, extending the right hand of fellowship as a sign of agreement on differentiated mission fields.
traits.symbolic_role: Functions in Paul’s narrative as a representative of the Jerusalem leadership who, at least at this point in the story, affirms Paul’s Gentile-focused gospel.
